user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
```c
static void metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap(struct metal_bus *bus,
				      struct metal_device *device,
				      uint32_t dir,
				      struct metal_sg *sg,
				      int nents)
{
	struct linux_device *ldev = to_linux_device(device);
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);

	ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_unmap(lbus, ldev, dir, sg,
				       nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_linux_dev_dma_unmap:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...

	const char		*bus_name;
	struct linux_driver	drivers[MAX_DRIVERS];
	struct sysfs_bus	*sbus;
}
...

	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
...

	const char             *name;       /**< Device name */
	struct metal_bus       *bus;        /**< Bus that contains device */
	unsigned int           num_regions; /**< Number of I/O regions in
						 device */
	struct metal_io_region regions[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS]; /**< Array of
							I/O regions in device*/
	struct metal_list      node;       /**< Node on bus' list of devices */
	int                    irq_num;    /**< Number of IRQs per device */
	void                   *irq_info;  /**< IRQ ID */
}
...

	struct metal_bus_ops	ops;

</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The struct member 'struct linux_driver *ldrv;' in struct linux_device is used only to call driver callbacks (e.g. ldev->ldrv->dev_dma_unmap(...)) and there is no evidence it is modified through this pointer. Per MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13, the pointer should be to a const-qualified type when possible (e.g. 'const struct linux_driver *ldrv;'). Therefore the current non-const pointer is a violation unless other code needs to modify the referenced linux_driver via this pointer.
